page.title: 04The River Medway
page.content: The{River Medway}flows from Ashdown Forest to its estuary in the North Sea.{Tonbridge}lies in the{Vale of {Kent}between forest ridges and here the Medway is in a flood plain. It should meander but in 19th century it was straightened and canalised. It was used by the Baltic Saw Mills for transporting timber and by Thames' barges carrying goods. Further canalising was stopped by the railway and industrial use of the river declined. The Medway has flooded Tonbridge many times but the worst flood was in{1968.}On{Saturday 15th {September}it began to rain and continued for{48 hours.}By Sunday night many homes were flooded, people stranded upstairs or prevented from returning home. The river flowed into the High Street and canoes, wrenched from moorings, smashed shop windows.
